fun_fact: Afghanistan's flag has been changed over 20 times since 1919!
Åland's flag features a Nordic cross, showing its ties to Finland and Sweden.
Albania's double-headed eagle has been a national symbol since the 15th century.
The star and crescent on Algeria's flag symbolize Islam and the nation's independence.
The eagle on American Samoa's flag represents the United States protecting the islands.
Andorra's flag shows the emblems of France and Spain, its neighboring countries.
The machete on Angola's flag represents the nation's struggle for independence.
Anguilla's dolphins symbolize unity, strength, and endurance.
Antarctica doesn’t have an official national flag, but this design is used internationally.
The rising sun on Antigua and Barbuda's flag represents a new era.
Argentina's Sun of May symbolizes freedom and independence.
The colors of Armenia's flag represent courage, loyalty, and creativity.
The red star on Aruba's flag represents the island and its four points of compass.
The stars of the Southern Cross constellation appear on Australia's flag.
Austria's flag is one of the oldest national flags in the world.
The crescent and star on Azerbaijan's flag symbolize Islam and Turkic heritage.
The black triangle on the Bahamas flag represents the people’s strength and will.
Bahrain's five white points symbolize the five pillars of Islam.
The red circle on Bangladesh's flag represents the sun and the blood of martyrs.
The trident on Barbados's flag represents independence from the UK.
Belarus' red and green colors symbolize the nation's history and fields.
Belgium’s black, yellow, and red are inspired by the coat of arms of the Duchy of Brabant.
Belize's flag is unique for showing two human figures in its coat of arms.
Benin’s green represents hope and yellow represents wealth.
Bermuda's flag has a red ensign with the Union Jack.
The dragon on Bhutan's flag represents the purity and protection of the nation.
Bolivia’s tricolor reflects the nation’s military, mineral wealth, and fertility.
Bosnia’s stars symbolize Europe and the nation’s hope for unity.
Botswana’s blue stands for water, a precious resource in the country.
Bouvet Island is uninhabited, but its flag is officially recognized.
Brazil’s flag has 27 stars, one for each state and the federal district.
This flag shows the Union Jack and palm tree for its tropical location.
Brunei’s flag features a parasol and hands symbolizing monarchy and protection.
Bulgaria’s colors symbolize peace, agriculture, and courage.
The star on Burkina Faso’s flag represents the guiding light of revolution.
Burundi’s three stars represent the nation’s motto: Unity, Work, Progress.
Angkor Wat on Cambodia’s flag is one of the world’s largest religious monuments.
Cameroon’s star represents unity for the nation.
The maple leaf on Canada’s flag is a symbol recognized worldwide.
The ten stars on Cape Verde’s flag represent its ten islands.
The Caribbean Netherlands consists of three special municipalities—Bonaire, Sint Eustatius, and Saba—and each island has its own unique culture and natural beauty.
The turtle on the Cayman Islands’ flag symbolizes the seafaring tradition.
The flag’s colors represent the four regions and France, its former colonial power.
Chad’s flag is almost identical to Romania’s flag!
The single star on Chile’s flag is called the ‘Star of Arauco’.
China’s flag has one big star and four smaller stars symbolizing the unity of the Chinese people.
The golden bosun bird on Christmas Island’s flag is native to the island.
The flag of the Cocos Islands includes a palm tree and a crescent on a blue field, reflecting the islands’ tropical environment and Islamic heritage of some residents.
Colombia’s yellow stripe represents its wealth and abundant gold.
Comoros’ crescent and stars symbolize Islam and the four islands of the nation.
The flag of the Republic of the Congo features a diagonal tricolor of green, yellow, and red, symbolizing the country’s forests, wealth, and struggle for independence.
The flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo features a star on a blue field, symbolizing the unity and hope of the people.
The 15 stars on Cook Islands’ flag symbolize its 15 islands.
Costa Rica’s flag colors symbolize the sky, peace, blood shed for freedom, and the sun.
The flag of Côte d'Ivoire consists of three vertical stripes of orange, white, and green, symbolizing the land’s fertility, peace, and hope for the future.
Croatia’s flag features a famous red-and-white checkerboard known as the ‘šahovnica’.
Cuba’s lone star represents independence and freedom.
The two stars represent the main island of Curaçao and the smaller island Klein Curaçao.
Cyprus’ flag features a map of the island to symbolize peace and neutrality.
The Czech flag design dates back to 1920 and survived the split from Slovakia.
Denmark’s flag, the Dannebrog, is the oldest continuously used national flag in the world.
The red star symbolizes unity and the blood shed for independence.
Dominica’s parrot is the only national bird to appear on a flag.
The Dominican flag features a Bible at the center of its coat of arms.
Ecuador’s flag has an Andean condor on the crest symbolizing power and protection.
Egypt’s eagle on the flag represents strength and sovereignty.
The flag’s triangle symbolizes equality and the blue stripes represent the oceans.
The flag of England, known as the St George's Cross, is a red cross on a white background and has been associated with England since the Middle Ages.
The silk-cotton tree on Equatorial Guinea’s flag represents the place where independence was declared.
Eritrea’s flag star represents the country’s unity and aspirations for the future.
Estonia’s flag colors symbolize the sky, soil, and purity.
Eswatini’s shield and spears symbolize protection from enemies.
Ethiopia’s flag inspired many African nations’ independence movements.
The sheep and ship on the flag highlight the islands’ main industries.
The cross on Faroe Islands’ flag represents Christianity.
Fiji’s flag shows a shield with sugarcane, coconut, and bananas, highlighting its agriculture.
Finland’s blue cross represents its many lakes.
The French flag is known as the Tricolore and symbolizes liberty, equality, fraternity.
The red star on French Guiana’s flag symbolizes socialism and hope.
French Polynesia’s flag shows a Polynesian canoe sailing the waves.
This flag represents French territories in remote southern oceans and Antarctica.
Gabon’s yellow stripe represents the equator, which runs through the country.
The blue stripe represents the Gambia River, the country’s lifeline.
Georgia’s flag is called the ‘Five Cross Flag’ and was revived in 2004.
The black, red, and gold colors have been associated with German unity since the 19th century.
The black star symbolizes African freedom and unity.
Gibraltar’s flag features a castle and key, symbolizing its strategic fortress.
Greece’s nine stripes represent the nine syllables of the phrase 'Freedom or Death'.
The red semicircle on Greenland’s flag represents the sun setting on the horizon.
The nutmeg on Grenada’s flag represents the country’s nickname: 'Island of Spice.'
Guadeloupe’s flag incorporates symbols of its French colonial heritage and tropical identity.
The coconut tree and river on Guam’s flag symbolize the island’s landscape and resources.
Guatemala’s quetzal bird represents liberty and independence.
Guernsey’s flag includes a gold cross representing the island’s connection to England.
The flag’s colors follow the Pan-African movement’s symbolism.
The black star represents African unity and freedom.
Guyana’s flag is nicknamed ‘The Golden Arrowhead.’
Haiti’s flag includes a coat of arms with a palm tree symbolizing independence.

The unofficial flag of Heard Island and McDonald Islands features a simple design with the Union Jack, as it is an Australian external territory, reflecting its governance rather than local symbolism.
The five stars represent the five nations of the former Federal Republic of Central America.
The five-petal Bauhinia flower represents harmony between Hong Kong and China.
Hungary’s flag colors symbolize strength, faithfulness, and hope.
The red cross represents the island’s volcanic fires.
The Ashoka Chakra has 24 spokes representing righteousness and progress.
Indonesia’s flag is called 'Sang Saka Merah Putih' meaning 'The Sacred Red and White.'
The emblem in the center represents the word Allah and a tulip, symbolizing martyrdom.
The Arabic inscription 'Allahu Akbar' means 'God is great.'
The green represents Catholics, orange Protestants, and white peace between them.
The triskelion symbol with three legs is unique to the Isle of Man.
The Star of David represents Jewish identity and heritage.
Italy’s flag colors were inspired by the uniforms of the Cisalpine Republic’s army.
The flag’s colors symbolize the people, natural wealth, and sunshine.
The red circle represents the sun; Japan is called the 'Land of the Rising Sun.'
Jersey’s flag incorporates the red cross of St. George and the island’s coat of arms.
The seven-pointed star represents the seven verses of the first surah in the Quran.
The sun and eagle symbolize freedom and the country’s future.
Kenya’s shield and spears symbolize defense of freedom.
The frigate bird represents power, freedom, and the sea.
The red star symbolizes communism and revolution.
The trigrams represent heaven, earth, water, and fire.
The flag of Kosovo features a blue field with a golden map of the country and six white stars, each representing one of the major ethnic groups living there.
Kuwait’s flag colors are traditional Pan-Arab colors.
The sun’s 40 rays represent the 40 tribes of Kyrgyzstan.
The white circle represents the unity of the people under the nation.
Latvia’s dark red symbolizes the readiness to defend freedom.
The cedar tree represents peace, immortality, and tolerance.
Lesotho’s hat symbol represents the traditional Basotho hat.
Liberia’s single star represents freedom and independence.
Libya’s crescent and star are symbols of Islam.
The crown symbolizes the unity of the people and the monarchy.
Yellow represents the sun, green the forests, and red the courage of the nation.
Luxembourg’s flag colors are similar to the Netherlands, but the shade of blue is lighter.
The flag of Macau has a green field with a white lotus flower above a stylized bridge and water, beneath an arc of five golden stars, symbolizing its connection to China.
The colors reflect the history of the Merina kingdom and French colonial influence.
The rising sun symbolizes the dawn of hope and freedom for Africa.
The 14 stripes represent the 13 states and the federal government.
The crescent symbolizes Islam, the national religion.
Mali’s flag follows the Pan-African colors, symbolizing hope, purity, and sacrifice.
The George Cross was awarded to Malta by King George VI in 1942 for bravery during WWII.
The 24-pointed star represents the number of electoral districts.
Martinique’s colonial-era flag features snakes, historically associated with the island.
The crescent and star symbolize Islam; the red stripes represent the blood shed for independence.
Each color represents a different aspect of the nation: red for independence, blue for the ocean, yellow for sunlight, and green for agriculture.
Mayotte’s flag features a coat of arms highlighting local culture and geography.
The eagle and snake symbolize an ancient Aztec legend about the founding of Tenochtitlán.
The four stars represent the four states of the Federated States of Micronesia.
The eagle holds a cross and scepter, symbolizing sovereignty and faith.
Monaco’s flag is nearly identical to Indonesia’s, but with different proportions.
The Soyombo symbol represents freedom, independence, and fire.
The lion represents courage and strength of Montenegro’s people.
The woman on the shield represents Erin, the symbol of Montserrat’s Irish heritage.
The green pentagram is called the Seal of Solomon and represents wisdom and peace.
The AK-47 on the flag symbolizes defense and vigilance.
The star symbolizes the union of Myanmar’s diverse ethnic groups.
The sun symbolizes life and energy; red stands for the people.
The white 12-pointed star represents the 12 original tribes of Nauru.
Nepal’s flag is the only national flag that is not quadrilateral.
The flag was derived from the Prince’s Flag during the Dutch Revolt.
The disc represents the sun rising over the land and the symbol of Kanak culture.
The four red stars represent the Southern Cross constellation.
The triangle represents equality, liberty, and fraternity.
The orange circle symbolizes the sun.
The green represents agriculture; white symbolizes peace.
The flag reflects Niue’s historical ties to the United Kingdom.
The Norfolk Island pine represents the island’s native flora.
The sunburst represents 'the new sun of liberty.'
The flag of Northern Ireland, known as the Ulster Banner, features a red cross on a white field with a six-pointed star, a red hand, and a crown, representing the historic province of Ulster.

The flag of the Northern Mariana Islands features a white star and a gray latte stone, which is a traditional Chamorro stone pillar, surrounded by a decorative wreath, symbolizing the islands' indigenous culture.
The cross represents Christianity; colors were inspired by France and Denmark.
White symbolizes peace, red represents battles against invaders, and green stands for fertility.
The white stripe represents religious minorities; the crescent represents progress.
The yellow circle symbolizes the moon, reflecting peace and tranquility.
The colors represent Pan-Arab colors of Arab unity and independence.
The stars symbolize the two political parties and the purity of the nation.
The Raggiana bird-of-paradise symbolizes the country’s rich wildlife.
Paraguay’s flag is unique with different designs on the front and back.
The vicuña on the crest represents Peru’s national animal.
The flag is flown upside down only in times of war.
The ship represents the HMS Bounty, central to the island’s history.
White symbolizes peace and purity, red represents the struggle for freedom.
The armillary sphere symbolizes Portugal’s Age of Exploration.
The single white star represents the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
The maroon color symbolizes bloodshed in Qatar’s history; the serrated edge has nine points.
The flag represents the island’s unique cultural diversity.
The colors represent liberty (blue), justice (yellow), and fraternity (red).
The colors have historic origins, representing the Russian Empire.
The sun represents enlightenment; blue for happiness and peace.
The coat of arms reflects the island’s colonial history.

country: Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha
fun_fact: The flag features the Union Jack in the canton and the coat of arms of Saint Helena, which represents the island's history, maritime heritage, and local wildlife.
The two stars represent the two islands of the federation.
The triangle represents the island’s famous Pitons mountains.
The flag is a French tricolor with a local coat of arms.
The ships symbolize the Basque, Breton, and Norman heritage of settlers.
The diamonds symbolize the islands’ nickname, 'The Gems of the Antilles.'
The Southern Cross constellation represents the country’s geographical location.
The crown atop the coat of arms symbolizes sovereignty.
The flag's two black stars represent the two main islands, and the green and yellow colors symbolize the rich vegetation and tropical climate of the country.
The inscription is the Islamic declaration of faith; the sword represents justice.
The Scottish flag, known as the Saltire or St. Andrew's Cross, is one of the oldest flags in the world, dating back to at least the 9th century.
The green star symbolizes hope and the country’s independence.
The double-headed eagle represents the Serbian Orthodox Church.
The angled bands represent a dynamic nation moving into the future.
Green symbolizes agriculture, white for unity, blue for the sea.
The crescent represents a young nation, the five stars represent democracy, peace, progress, justice, and equality.
The rising sun symbolizes a new beginning for the country.
The double cross represents Christianity; the three hills represent the Tatra, Fatra, and Matra mountains.
The three stars represent the Counts of Celje, a historical dynasty.
The five stars represent the five main island groups.
The white five-pointed star symbolizes unity of the Somali people.
The Y-shape represents the convergence of diverse elements in South African society.
The flag features the Union Jack and the territory’s coat of arms, highlighting its status as a British Overseas Territory in the South Atlantic
The star symbolizes unity of the states in South Sudan.
The two red stripes represent the bloodshed during battles; yellow represents generosity.
The lion represents the Sinhalese ethnicity, and the sword symbolizes sovereignty.
Red symbolizes the struggle for freedom; black represents Sudan itself.
The yellow star represents unity of all ethnic groups in the country.
The flag is based on Norway’s flag, reflecting administrative ties.
The yellow cross represents Christianity.
The Swiss flag is square, one of only two square national flags.
The two green stars originally represented Syria and Egypt during the United Arab Republic.
The white sun with twelve rays represents the twelve months and twelve traditional Chinese hours.
The crown and seven stars symbolize the unity of the Tajik people.
Green represents land, blue for the sea, yellow for minerals, and black for people.
Red represents the land and people, white for religions, and blue for the monarchy.
The yellow triangle represents the traces of colonialism; the black triangle represents struggles for independence.
The five stripes represent the five regions of Togo.
The flag depicts a traditional Polynesian canoe navigating the Southern Cross.
The red cross represents Christianity.
Red represents the sun, white for sea, black for strength.
The crescent and star symbolize Islam.
The crescent and star have long been symbols of the Ottoman Empire.
The five carpet patterns represent the five major tribes of Turkmenistan.
The flag shows the Union Jack and the territory’s coat of arms, which includes a conch shell, a lobster, and a cactus, symbolizing the islands’ marine life and natural environment.
The nine stars represent the nine islands of Tuvalu.
The grey crowned crane represents Uganda’s national bird.
Blue represents the sky, yellow represents wheat fields.
The colors represent Arab unity: red for courage, green for fertility, white for peace, black for strength.
The flag combines the crosses of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
The 50 stars represent the 50 states; 13 stripes represent the original colonies.
The flag is a variant of the U.S. flag, often using the standard stars and stripes, representing the islands’ status as unincorporated territories of the United States.
The Sun of May represents freedom and independence.
The crescent represents the rebirth of Uzbekistan; 12 stars for the months.
The emblem features a boar’s tusk, a symbol of prosperity.
The keys represent the keys to Heaven given to Saint Peter.
The eight stars represent the provinces that joined in independence.
The yellow star represents the leadership of the Communist Party over workers, peasants, soldiers, intellectuals, and youth.
The flag features the Union Jack and the territory's coat of arms, which depicts Saint Ursula holding a gold lamp, referencing the islands' name origin.
The flag features an eagle holding a laurel branch and three arrows, symbolizing peace and the three main islands: Saint Thomas, Saint John, and Saint Croix.
The Welsh flag features a red dragon, a symbol of strength and courage, which has been associated with Wales for centuries.
The flag incorporates the French Tricolor, reflecting its overseas territory status.
The crescent and star symbolize Islam.
Red represents unity and struggle, white symbolizes a bright future, and black the dark past.
The eagle represents the freedom and ability to rise above the nation’s problems.
The Zimbabwe Bird is a national emblem and historic symbol of the nation.
